subject: Parenting
title: Delayed vs Immediate Consequences
description: A 1-minute de-risking session on Delayed vs Immediate Consequences.

hook.text: 'Wait until your father gets home.' That threat is ineffective. Here's why.

buildup.text: Young children's brains connect cause and effect within a narrow time window.

discovery.text: For children under five, a consequence must follow the behavior within minutes to be effective.

twist.text: A delayed consequence teaches the child to fear the person delivering it ‚Äî not to change the behavior.

climax.text: Older children can handle delayed consequences, but even for them, immediacy improves learning.

punchline.text: A consequence that arrives too late teaches nothing except dread.

quiz.question: Why are delayed consequences ineffective for young children?
options: Their brains can only connect cause and effect within minutes
Delayed consequences are always more effective
